profiles.name: Octopus
clues: Lives as a marine invertebrate without backbone
Has eight flexible appendages for movement
Found in coral reefs and ocean floor

profiles.name: Lion
clues: Known as the king of the jungle
Native to Africa and small parts of Asia
Roar can be heard 5 miles away
Cubs have spots that fade with age
Can run up to 50 mph for short distances
Featured in many myths and legends

profiles.name: Penguin
clues: Cannot fly as flightless bird species
Known as excellent swimmer in water
Found in Antarctica and nearby regions
Mates for life in some species
Lays eggs on ice or land
Males of largest species incubate eggs on feet
Slides on belly to move efficiently
Natural predators include seals and orcas

profiles.name: Elephant

Has valuable ivory tusks for defense

profiles.name: Dolphin
clues: Lives as marine mammal in ocean

profiles.name: Eagle

American species is US national symbol
Has excellent eyesight for spotting prey

profiles.name: Tiger
clues: Known as excellent swimmer in water

profiles.name: Giraffe
clues: Herbivore eating leaves from tall trees

clues: Active as nocturnal hunter at night

profiles.name: Albatross
clues: Largest wingspan of any living bird reaching up to 11 feet
Spends most of life gliding over ocean waters
Can travel thousands of miles without flapping wings
Feeds on fish, squid, and krill at sea surface
Returns to same island annually for breeding
Mates for life in long-term partnerships
Can live over 50 years in wild
Found primarily in Southern Hemisphere oceans
Ancient mariners considered them sacred birds
Uses dynamic soaring technique to minimize energy use
Produces distinctive braying calls during courtship
Nests in colonies on remote islands
Takes over 10 years to reach breeding age
Symbol in literature and maritime folklore
Threatened by fishing nets and plastic pollution
Albino variant occasionally observed in populations
Can drink seawater using special glands
Chicks fledge only once per year
Conservation dependent species in many regions

profiles.name: Lemming
clues: Small rodent living in Arctic tundra regions
Famous for population cycles lasting about 4 years
Can survive extremely cold temperatures below -40Â°C
Builds elaborate tunnel systems under snow
Herbivore eating grasses, sedges, and mosses
Has thick winter coat for insulation
Predators include owls, foxes, and weasels
Legend of mass suicide migrations is false
Can have multiple litters in single season
Some species show color change with seasons
Native to Arctic regions of North America, Europe, Asia
Creates runways through vegetation for travel
Has relatively short lifespan of 1-3 years
Plays important role in Arctic food chains
Population crashes support predator population swings
Weight fluctuates with seasonal food availability

profiles.name: Macaque
clues: Largest primate genus with over 20 species
Native to Asia across wide geographic range
Live in troops with complex social hierarchies
Highly adaptable to various habitats from tropical to temperate
Can thrive in mountainous regions with snow
Omnivorous diet including fruits, leaves, and insects
Use hands skillfully to manipulate objects and tools
Communicate through facial expressions and vocalizations
Female-biased social structures in many species
Groom each other to strengthen social bonds
Some populations show cultural behaviors passed down
Play behavior important for young development
Some species show tolerance for human proximity
High genetic similarity to human primates
Vulnerable to habitat loss and illegal trade

profiles.name: Viper
clues: Found on every continent except Antarctica
Some species have elaborate warning displays
Heat pits allow detection of warm-blooded prey
Can control amount of venom injected
Specialized fang structure for venom delivery
Carnivore eating rodents, birds, and other animals
Some species give live birth rather than laying eggs
Can remain motionless for extended periods
Venom composition varies by species and geography
Pit organs provide thermal imaging capability
Responsible for significant human snake bite incidents
Wide distribution from deserts to rainforests
Some species have elaborate head patterns
Shed skin multiple times throughout life
Play crucial ecological role controlling rodent populations

profiles.name: Tapir
clues: Native to Central and South America and Southeast Asia
Herbivore using flexible proboscis to gather vegetation
Three toes on hind feet and four on front feet
Semi-aquatic lifestyle spending time in rivers
Nocturnal foragers active during night hours
Solitary animals except during mating season
Distinctive black and white coloring on some species
Ancient lineage with fossil record spanning millions of years
Play important seed dispersal role in ecosystems
Can weigh between 300-700 pounds depending on species
Vulnerable to habitat loss from deforestation
Create trails through forest that other animals use
Pregnant females carry young for about 13 months
Calves stay with mother for approximately 2 years
Communicate through whistles and other vocalizations
Have poor eyesight but excellent sense of smell
Classified as vulnerable by conservation organizations

profiles.name: Gharial
clues: Extremely long and narrow snout adapted for fishing
Males develop large nasal knob at snout tip
Critically endangered species with limited populations
Found primarily in rivers of India and Nepal
Eggs laid in holes dug in sand
Temperature determines sex of developing embryos
Teeth designed specifically for gripping slippery fish
Historically more widespread across South Asia
Conservation breeding programs working to increase numbers
Vulnerable to river pollution and dam construction
Diet of 95% fish makes them specialized predators
Cannot survive in saltwater unlike other crocodilians
Vocalizations include hissing and grunting sounds
Significant cultural importance in Indian mythology
